H0.text: Mass is the most likely difference between the two pieces of pure copper that a teacher breaks into different sized pieces.

H1.text: Texture is the most likely difference between the two pieces of a pure copper bar that a teacher breaks into two different sized pieces.

H2.text: The boiling point is the most likely difference between the two differently sized pieces of pure copper that the teacher breaks from the bar.

H3.text: Melting point is the most likely difference between the two pieces of pure copper when a teacher breaks a bar of copper into two different sized pieces.

A4.text: At the macroscopic scale, introduction of extended defects to the crystal lattice, such as grain boundaries, hinders flow of the material under applied stress, thereby increasing its hardness.

A5.text: Mass is not the same as weight, even though mass is often determined by measuring the object's weight using a spring scale.

A6.text: An object on the Moon would weigh less than it does on Earth because of the lower gravity, but it would still have the same mass.
